February 23, 1990

President George Bush received an honorary Doctor of
Humane Letters degree as part of
the Commemoration Day exercises held in Shriver Hall yesterday afternoon, along with five
distinguished scientists. Twenty
eight former postdoctoral fellows
and faculty members were also
inducted into the University's
Society of Scholars.
In an impressive show of
academic pomp, the Faculty and
Trustees marched into Shriver to
musical fanfares by Georg
Friedrich Handel and Walter
Piston. Many of the professors
who were to be inducted into the
University's Society of Scholars
wore gowns and caps unique to
their institutions.
In the audience were Louis
Sullivan, Secretary of Health
and Human Services, Governor
William Donald Schaefer of
Maryland, and Representative
Helen Bentley.
Commemoration Day, held
each February 22, marks the anniversary of the founding of
Johns Hopkins University. This
year is the 114th Anniversary of
the University, as well as the
centennial of the medical
institutions.
In front of an audience of faculty, administrators, invited guests
and students, University President Steven Muller spoke of

Hopkins' founding in 1876, and
stressed the fundamental change
in higher education the Hopkins
model represents—the modern
research university.
"The Johns Hopkins University was created as a nurturing environment for research and a
place for advanced study...[It
was] endowed with the spirit of
a university unique at that time.
The desi n of this hos•ital direct-

ly related patient care functions
to medical education and
research."
After Richard Ross, dean of the
School of Medicine, had cited
Bush's
political
accomplishments, Muller conferred
the honorary degree on Bush in
front of an enthusiastic crowd.

The Hopkins Board of Trustees
has moved to create a special endowment in honor of retiring
University President Steven
Muller. The Steven Muller Endowment for the Humanities will
be earmarked for the Arts and
Sciences division of Hopkins.
A fundraising drive to establish
the endowment has already
begun, with letters of solicitation
being sent out to alumni, friends
of the University, and parents of
current students.
The endowment fund will be
"in recognition of his innovative
and imaginative leadership land
his] more than 18 years of service
as president of Johns Hopkins."
While the endowment of
Hopkins as a whole, valued at
over $527 million last year, is
sizable, most of the endowment
monies are destined for the
Hopkins medical institutions.
The endowment of Hopkins'
Arts and Sciences is considerably
less than that of comparable
schools. Increasing the Arts and
Sciences endowment of Hopkins
has long been one of Muller's
stated goals.
According to promotional
literature for the endowment fund
drive, Muller has long warned
against turning out "highly skilled barbarians," a fault of many
major research universities.
"What must Hopkins do?"
continued Muller. "Carry out its
well-established mission of
discovering and training at the
highest level and in such a way
as to keep standing out in future
decades as a bulwark of human
civilization, . . .an anchor of
values and purpose in the sea of
change.
"What about the notion of
transmitting civilization,/ of
transmitting the best of the past
to the future? That may be the
most critical question that
American system of higher
education faces, and that
therefore the Johns Hopkins
University faces."

An integral step in the evolutionary cycle that brought us up

up for morning workout the night
before.
In any event. This particular
roommate of mine is what we call
a "heavy sleeper," which really
means that he requires a
defibrillator to regain consciousness every morning. Accordingly, he has an alarm clock
that is Armageddon itself. It's
your standard radio-alarm issue,

circa 1975 or so, with flipswitches instead of touchsensitive buttons. Ah, but then,

In an effort to drag himself out

Snooze Alarm.

Bush: Less than humane
While President George Bush and Hopkins dignitaries participated in Commemoration Day exercises in Shriver Hall,
several Hopkins-affiliated groups gathered in protest, in the
rain, on the steps of Levering Hall. Students and other members
of the Homewood community, including such diverse groups
as the Women's Center, Students for Environmental Action,
the Progressive Student Union and the School of Public Health,
rallied against the University's decision to select President Bush
as the speaker for the Commemoration Day theme: "Doctoring in America."
During the ceremony Bush received an honorary Doctor of
Humane Letters degree. Unfortunately, the Bush Adminstration's actions toward public health have been less than humane.
In this fiscal year alone, the Administration proposes to cut
federal public health expenditures by 7 percent. The Administration has already limited Medicaid funding for abortions,
and deeply cut funding for family planning centers and contraceptive research.

With the importance that Bush claims to place on the notion
of family and American values, how is it that 500,000 women
each year give birth to children without medical care and that
42 percent of families headed by single women live beneath
the poverty line? A consequence of this poverty is that 40,000
infants die in their first year; one-half of these deaths can be
prevented with increased access to prenatal and maternal health
care
These facts and figures should be kept in mind when Bush
speaks of his Administration's commitment to health care. He
refers to Secretary Sullivan's evaluation of cost, quality,and
effectiveness of care, and of a program to study overall treatment. Such kind and gentle rhetoric is nice enough when looking down from the House on the hill, but an active public health
policy is long overdue. Surely a more appropriate Commemoration speaker than President Bush could have been found to
discuss "Doctoring in America."

A new mission for Johns Hopkins
While President Muller has done a great deal for the Johns
Hopkins University as a whole over the past twenty years, the
undergraduate division has not received as much attention as
it deserves. While the School of Arts and Sciences still offers
a combination of small classes and a truly worldly faculty that
few schools can match, current budgetary problems have shaken
student confidence in the University's commitment to its
undergraduates.
Our next president must respond to this unease not with
dollars alone, but with a revolutionary approach to
undergraduate education: It is time to reinstitute the core curriculum and, in the liberal arts, the mandatory senior thesis.
These must be part of a three-pronged philosophy which will
decisively set a Hopkins undergraduate education apart from
all other universities.
First, our liberal arts must be kept from falling into the abyss
of grade inflation which scars so many other schools; an 'A'
should be a rare occurrence. One step towards arresting the slide
towards grade inflation (still far more controlled here than at
Yale or Stanford—average grades at those schools are said to
be nearly 3.8) is to reintroduce the mandatory senior thesis,
a victim of the turbulent 1960's. It is ludicrous that English,
Writing Seminars, and Political Science majors, for example,
are not required to submit a supervised thesis in order to
graduate. A thesis is an invaluable learning experience, and
would allow professors and future employers/graduate schools
to see if students had gotten anything out of four expensive
years. It would also put Hopkins on the academic map as a
school which was extremely serious about substantive

undergraduate liberal arts education.
Second, all students, whether in the sciences or in the
humanities, should begin with a common core curriculum.
Twenty-five years ago, all Hopkins students had to take two
terms of Occidental Civilization. This should be reinstated, in
conjunction with courses which reflect the globalization of late
twentieth-century life. Liberal arts students must also be required to take some hard sciences. The idea that such students
don't need a strong quantitative background is absurd and hardly befits an institution with Hopkins' ancestry.
Third, the University must keep class sizes down. The difficulty some professors are already having with hordes of
students begging for their seminars is alarming. Either the
University must expand its course offerings, or accept fewer
students. There are plenty of professors who do not teach much,
if at all. And there are plenty of other schools where sharp
undergraduates can go if they receive inadequate instruction
here. Worst of all, large classes are a betrayal of Hopkins'
greatest claim to fame: academic intimacy.
A well-conceived philosophy of what an undergraduate
education at Hopkins should be would help to restore confidence
in the Arts and Sciences, and would lend greater meaning to
what is often an unpleasant grind. The promotion of a core curriculum and the return of such challenges as the senior thesis,
would restore the lustre which is often missing from liberal
arts degrees, and broaden the minds of sometimes myopic scientists. Most of all, a clear philosophy, based on this University's unique and proud past, would give the Arts and Sciences
a sense of direction and meaning.

In tht Age of Show Business
everything is entertaining. With
the ascension of television as our
main brm of public discourse,
Americans have come to expect
that even the most serious topics
be broaght to them in an exciting
visual manner. Nowhere is this
more evident than a typical
broadcast of network news. The
musical theme, attractive
graphcs, and handsome anchornen offer a smooth transition
from television's normal programining. While the viewer is
expected to distinguish between
sitcoms and public information,
the harmat of network news
makes this a difficult process. As
Robert MacNeil of the MacNeilLehrer News Hour has suggested, the assumptions controlling a news program are "that
bite-sized is best, that complexity must be avoided, that nuances
are dispensable, that qualifications impede the simple message,
that visual stimulation is a
substitu:e for thought, and that
is an
verbal precision
anachronism." This condemnation o television news may
distress the daily viewer, but it
should not come as a surprise.
Entertainment is the business of
television and news programs are
no exception.
Television news is never
presented in context. It would
take most of the evening to explain the intricacies in the British
Government every time a decision by Prime Minister Thatcher
was anncunced. Without this
information,
backgrotmd
however, the decision becomes
just another fact in a series of
fragmen:s presented by the
newscas:er. Incredibly, most
Americans cannot recall a single
item of news just a few minutes
after watching a news program.
This is he direct result of television's eniphasis on entertainment.
The viewer's ability to mentally
address each topic is curtailed by
a rapid succession of visual images accompanied by unsubstantive commentary. There is no
time for rational thought. The
viewer is set adrift in a sea of
trivia and told to fend for himself.
Television news must accomplish the dual goals of relaying information in an entertaining and rapid manner. The
average length of each shot on a
network sitcom is 3.5 seconds.
On a typical edition of the evening news, it is approximately two
seconds. One can hardly keep up

with the overwhelming visual
display and still distinguish what
is important. A story on Mikhail
Gorbachev's speech in West Germany might be accompanied by
images of people cheering in the
streets, opinion polls, and the
White House, all of which have
only a tenuous relationship to the
content of the presentation. The
story is then followed by a
McDonald's commercial, which
is accompanied by images of people cheering in the streets, opinion polls, and the White House,
all of which have only a tenuous
relationship to the product being
marketed. The juxtaposition
seems clear.
The real problem with television news is that it is on television. It might help to draw a comparison. Though the smoke signal
was once a popular form of communication, it is safe to assume
that Indians did not discuss the
meaning of life through this
medium. Muchawapeh would
have run out of wood before he
was able to convey his first
philosophic axiom to the
neighboring tribe. The form
denied the content. Television
news is faced with a similar
dilemma. With its emphasis on
visual imagery, television works
against the presentation of ideas.
Images supersede the content of
any verbal message. It would be
difficult to concentrate on the
news if the anchormen came on
without his clothes. His appearance would mitigate his ability to present information. Less
outlandish images produce the
same effect. The form of television serves as a barrier to effective communication except on a
basic, emotional level.
Neil Postman has suggested
that "The problem with television
is not that it presents us with
entertaining subject matter, but
that it presents all subject matter
as entertaining." Nowhere is this
more evident than in the format
of television news. Producers are
confined by a medium that does
not allow for the same rational
presentation of ideas as does the
written word. One would not
pause in a book for a commercial
break. When television attempts
to present serious discourse it is
simply doing its viewers a disservice. In its own way television is
as limited as the smoke signal.
Only when we realize this can we
understand that the line between
knowledge and ignorance is easily blurred.

To the Editors:
As the current editor of the

obligated to respond to the

Editorship" contained in last edition's Opinion section. Although

criticism. The distinction made in
the editorial between editorship
and censorship can be considered
as nothing other than a feeble attempt to legitimate the NewsLetter's recent abuses. The argument that internal editorial productions, such as Mr. Rosen's
strip, are subject to the same
restrictions as other internal productions, and that censorship
therefore isn't censorship when
the internal editorial productions
are the objects of such action is

ludicrous. If an internal editorial
production is thought to be
obscene or libelous, it can be considered the responsibility of an
editor to prevent its publication;
however, this same responsibility exists with regard to external
editorial materials submitted for
publication. That an editorial
should be subject to further
restrictions just because it is produced internally is difficult to see.
Because of the News-Letter's
disclaimer, it cannot be said that
an editorial's internal origin
necessarily implies editorial
board endorsement; furthermore,
Mr. Rosen's separate identity in
the eyes of the public made his
cartoons distinctly personal
statements. Finally, it must be
wondered what the News-Letter
hopes to accomplish by applying
a double standard to editorial
commentary. If it is considered
valuable to place only minimal
restrictions upon outside contributions, why is it less desirable
to be equally liberal in publishing
editorial commentary submitted
from the inside? I can only hope
that the News-Letter recognizes
the folly of this new policy in the
very near future.
Brian D. Kennedy
Editor

Steinberg on schisms:
Rabbi discusses divisions
throughout Jewish history

by Neeli Ben-David

by Shani Miller
The Union of Jewish Graduate
Students lecture series is back for
the spring semester. Last week's
speaker was Rabbi Benjamin
Steinberg, principal of the Bais
Yaakov School. The evening's
topic was "Schisms in Judaism."
Rabbi Steinberg began the lecture with the joke of the Jew who
was shipwrecked on a dessert
island: the man built two
synagogues, one to pray in and
one in which he would not be
caught dead.
Steinberg then discussed
various schisms in Jewish history,
beginning with the Biblical accounts of Korah rebelling against
Moses and the later formation of
the breakaway Kingdom on Israel
from the Kingdom of Judah.
Steinberg established two
general types of splits: ones that
operate "within the parameters of
Judaism" and ones that operate
from without.
He cited the case of HiIlel and
Shammai, two eminent rabbis
who lived roughly 2000 years
ago and who disagreed on nearly every major issue that came
before them. This difference in
rabbinical opinion did not cause
the divisiveness that characterized other schisms such as the birth
of the Sadducees.
The Sadducees rejected rabbinical
authority completely and based
their interpretation of the Bible on
a literal understanding of the text.
What developed was a sect whose
rituals only slightly resembled
those of traditional Judaism.
Hillel and Shammai disagreed
within the traditional legal
framework of Judaism; both of
their opinions remained within
the philosophical bounds of
Judaism. But the Sadducees rejected rabbinical authority come

0

pletely, and as rabbinical
leadership is essential to the integrity of the religion, this crisis
resulted in a major schism.
Similarly, early Christianity
was loosely based on Jewish
traditions. However, since it rejected the Temple services and
revoked the Sabbath as the traditional day of rest, it was largely
unpopular with the Jewish community. The Temple was a major symbol to the Jews, and the
Sabbath even today remains an
integral part of Jewish life.
Here again was a case of a
group moving beyond the bounds
of traditional Judaism. The difference between the Sadducees
and Christianity is that Christianity drew non-Jewish converts and
evolved into its own religion,
while the Sadducees remained a
strictly Jewish sect.
Steinberg moved on to the
Karaite schism in 700 A.D. in
Babylonia. Mirroring the Sadducees, the Karaites reject the
rabbinical authority. In the 1100's
Maimonides noted in his essays
that the Karaites remained Jews.
There is even a small community of Karaites still in existence in
the Old City of Jerusalem.
Steinberg followed with a quick
review of European history
leading to the formation of
Reform and Conservative
Judaism. He noted that the
Reform movement was an
outgrowth of the German
Enlightenment, the Age of
Reason. There was a general deemphasis of religion on the continent at the time, and by the turn
of the nineteenth century there
was a tremendous push to
simplify Jewish tradition and
ritual.
Conservatism was born out of
a concern that the Reform had

Jimmy Smith's Latest Album
A Shrewd Pastiche of Styles
Jimmy Smith—Prime Time
(Milestone)
Jimmy Smith has been a
premier jazz organist for nearly
35 years, and his first record
since 1985 is an impressive,
democratic collection of songs
and styles that reach as far back
as the swing era. "Straightahead" is how his record company describes it, but don't
believe it. Although "Prime
Time" is composed both of standards and some competent
originals, Smith and his band tug
this music in directions that are
both beguiling and unexpected.
The tugging isn't random,
however: Smith dips shrewdly into the wells of big band, bebop,
rhythm and blues, and even free
jazz to enhance his arrangements.
What makes it all so democratic
is the unfailing subtlety that, time
and again, wrings a convincing
result from the most unlikely
sources. Some of the players in
Smith's band (e.g. the tenor saxophonists) don't always meet the
challenge; the rhythm section
seems at times to play it safe for
their benefit. But the organist
himself is sensational, punching
out rich clusters of bass notes and

tiptoeing through sparse treble
runs that drift elegantly over the
rhythm section.
Tellingly, the most familiar
compositions on "Prime Time"
are also those that most succeed.
Kenny Burrell's "Here Comes
C.T.," written for trumpeter
Clark Terry, is at once strident
and funky. The perennial
"Honky Tonk" boasts an arrangement that puts the highs
where the lows should be, and
vice versa, but somehow it
works—and Smith revivifies one
of the most tired tunes in jazz.
The album's highlight, however,
is a dense rendition of Duke Ellington's "C Jam Blues." Here
the funk is all but absent, and
Smith's sextet expounds with the
energy and economy of a fullfledged big band.
—T.H. Kern

Victory for Paul Brickman
by Mark Friedman
Mid-winter movie surprises are
few and far between, but Paul
Brickman's "Men Don't Leave"
is a triumph of style and
substance. Shot predominantly in
Baltimore, the film manipulates
reality in an honest way. It provokes emotions, but doesn't leave
a residue of embarassment
afterwards.
Beth Macauley (Jessica
Lange), her husband John (Tom
Mason) and sons Matt (Charlie
Korsko) and Chris (Chris O'Donnell) live the good life in rural
Maryland. John's an architect,
the kids are attractive and responsible, and Beth cooks them meals
from the four basic food groups.
Everything's in order, but it
doesn't take a genius to realize
that things aren't going to stay
that way.
When John is killed in an explosion, "Men Don't Leave"

shifts into surreal overdrive. Beth
wanders aimlessly through
hospital corridors (Johns Hopkins
Hospital, to be precise) to identify his body. She ends up in a kitchen basement, slumping into a
corner as endless rows of Asian
employees slice up raw chicken
for hospital meals.
This is just one of Brickman's
peculiar but compelling visual
selections. "Men Don't Leave"
opens with stunning expressive
images of Matt racing a train as
he runs towards his home on a
rainy night; it's as if Brickman
were holding a carrot in front of
his camera. And then Matt is inside, his gentle voice reminiscing
about his salvation, his father rubbing and kneading his feet between his hands in front of a fire.
Like the rest of "Men Don't
Leave," the opener is a visual
knockout. These moments set the
tone for the film, presenting the
remarkably commonplace in a

way that seems daring and tender.
It's quite a trick. Brickman's only other work is the indelible
"Risky Business.," and the product here is equally jazzy and
challenging.
Brickman and co-writer Barbara Benedek ("The Big Chill")
nicely understate the family's
tremendous emotional trauma. In
scene after scene, Beth states the
facts of the situation, while
Brickman's pans of the children's
faces provide clues to the contrary. Lange is a gifted actress
giving a precise performance; the
work is far more dynamic than
her Oscar-nominated role in the
'mediocre "Music Box."

in her attempts to start a new relationship with Charles (Arliss

Why is there fluoride in toothpaste?
It's a good idea to brush after sweets, since sugar is food for bacteria
that live in your mouth. These bacteria produce acids which eat away
at the enamel, the mineral outer coat of teeth. The inner layer, the
dentine, is weaker and more sensitive to the acids and will start to
rot away without a protective enamel surface.
The minerals get stuck in the plaque, but teeth do reclaim them,
and fluoride appears to speed the process.
Also, enamel on children's teeth is developing. The little fluoride
ion probably steps in for bigger minerals, producing a tighter, and
thus stronger, crystal structure of enamel.

places 1 through 8 from the
prelims) and a consolation heat
(for places 9 to 16), which determine the points to be awarded to
the teams and individuals.
Despite the comments that
were overheard about the
Hopkins men being noncontenders for this meet, and the
\wren having a smali-rossibility of fighting for second place,
the Jays went into the meet with
an extremely positive attitude.
Both teams were defending champions in the UAA, and all of the

swimmers felt extremely wellrested. In fact, the statements only served to spur the team on as
they decided that they would prove everyone wrong. And they did
so decisively.
The initial day of events set the
tone for the entire meet. Both
teams would take the lead with
the first event and never relinquish it. As Assistant Coach Jim
"Popeye" Cutrone said, "We
dominated the meet from the first
day on. It was an excellent
meet."
The other teams began to question their assuredness when, in
the second event of the day, the
first heat of the Men's 200 yard
freestyle relay, freshman Eric
Steidinger led off with a time of
20.93 seconds—a time that would
have crushed the pool and UAA
records had it been set in an individual event. It did, however,
represent the first male swimming member of the Hopkins team
to qualify for the NCAA Division
III Championships. He was
followed by classmate Aaron
Osborne with a split of 20.7
seconds off of a relay start. The
relay was filled out by freshmen
Mike Zelman and Ryan Gill, who
finished with a time of
1:25.86—a new pool, UAA,and
Hopkins record that would last
until that evening when Steidinger
was joined by junior Steve
Muchow and seniors Mike Costa
and John Hsu to win the event
with a time of 1:24.26. When
asked about the fact that the B
relay (usually the slower relay)
was led by such quick sprinters,
Cutrone merely responded that it
was a Freshman Relay, an indication of continuing excellence in

the future.
The domination of the Jays did
not end with that event. On the
first night, 94 percent of the
Hopkins swimmers who swam in
the morning made it to the evening heats (33 of 35), and in that
first night Hopkins had six firstplace winners (two individual)
and three second-place swimmers. Junior Melanie Chellman
took first in the 200-yard individual medley and in the process set a new pool record, and
qualified for the 1990 Hopkins
national team. After being
sidelined with an elbow injury for
the first half of the season,junior
John Paul Munnich qualified for
Nationals with a second place
time of 4:42.27 in the 500-yard
freestyle. "I really didn't believe
I would qualify this year," said
Munnich once the truth had sunk
in.
The first day was not one of
complete happiness. Senior co-

captain Mary Price missed the
qualifying standard in the 50 yard
freestyle by 1/100th of a second;
she touched the wall with a
season best time of 25.16
seconds.
On the second day, the coaches
hoped for an even better performance as they felt that Hopkins
was stronger in the featured
events than those of the previous
day. Surprisingly, the only individual qualifiers for the
Hopkins national team were not
event winners. Freshman
Danielle Bird took third place in
the 200-yard freestyle with a time
of 1:58.67, and classmate Jim
Quinn finished the 100-yard
freestyle with a time of 1:00.08
and second place. Both the men's
and women's 800 freestyle relay
teams also qualified for Nationals
as each captured first place, as
well as the pool record. Hopkins
also took first and second place
in both the men's and women's

100-yard backstroke. Price and
junior co-captain Amy Parke
(1:03.41 and 1:04.03) took the
honors in the women's event,
while seniors Mark Rhoades and
Chris Hussin did so for the men
with times of 55.00 and 55.08
respectively. Junior Scott Herrick
also showed tremendous ability
when he took first place in 400
yard individual medley and set a
new pool record with a time of
4:16.66.
The final night of competition
was accompanied by an air of excitement, as the teams began with
cheers for themselves and for
each other. The University of
Chicago performed an army/synchronized swimming/diving exhibition cheer that included the
new found respect that the other
teams had found for Hopkins.

After beating
Western
Maryland convincingly to earn

champions. The loss eliminated

record, the best ever for a

Hopkins women's basketball
team. Two of the losses were in
overtime to national top-ten
Franklin & Marshall, and another
loss was by three points to
Washington University, then
ranked sixth in the nation.
In the Moravian loss, Sylke
Knuppel led the Jays in scoring
with 14 points while shooting
67% from the field and grabbing
seven rebounds. Sophomore
center Julie Slye and sophomore

forward Kerni McTiernan each
pulled down a game-high I 1
boards, as Hopkins outrebounded the Greyhounds 52-44.
Point guard Tracy Williams
handed out six assists in addition
to scoring 10 points and making
four steals. Junior tri-captain
Kristie Kantowski, the only other
Jay in double-figures, added 10 ,
points and five rebounds.
The Jays' leading scorer of the
season, tri-captain Juliane
Rolapp, was held to only nine
points before fouling out. Rolapp
also had five assists and four
rebounds.
With two minutes left in the
game, Hopkins was ahead 59-55,
but Moravian scored five quick
unanswered points to take a 60-59
lead. Rolapp was called for an intentional foul, disqualifying her
with less than one minute to play.
The Greyhounds' Julie Endler,
who led all scorers with 27
points, sank both free-throws to
put her team up 62-59 with 23
seconds left in the game. Another
foul gave Moravian a one-andone opportunity, but the shooter
only made the first, putting Moravian up 63-59. Sylke Knuppel
missed a three-pointer, but the
Jays sank the rebound as time ran
out.
Hopkins led Moravian in
almost every statistical category,
but Moravian made 7-of-18 from
three-point range while the Jays
shot only 1-for-2 from behind the
stripe. Hopkins held Moravian to
a mere 37% field-goal shooting,
while the Jays shot 39% from the
field for the game.

The Johns Hopkins ice hockey
team started its spring semester
season by going 1-1-1 last week.
As a result of the busy week of
action, the team pushed its record
to 10-5-1 overall and 6-3-1 in the
Mason Dixon League.
The Jays started the week with
a home game against Bucknell.
Hopkins jumped out to a two-goal
lead early in the first period on
goals by seniors Jack Calkins and
Pierre DeMatos but proved
unable to hold the lead. The effects of the long Christmas layoff
were evident as the Jays combined sloppy defensive play and an
uninspired offense on the way to
losing a 5-2 decision.
In the next contest, the Blue
Jays rebounded with a narrow 6-5
win at UMBC. Despite missing
the entire second line for the
game, Hopkins used tenacious

forechecking and a hawking
defense to overcome the absence
of key players. Jack Calkins lead
the offense by recording a
hat trick, while Craig Hampton
and Mike Holmes anchored the
defense.
The game saw four lead
changes, but a tired Blue Jay
squad was able to hold on to a late
6-5 lead due largely to superb
goaltending by Pierre Chevrier.
"I was really proud of the way
our guys hung in there. The other
team had superior personnel this
day, but we wanted it more,"
commented coach Steve Wirth.
Looking to follow one win with
another, the Jays traveled to
Dickinson to take on the Red
Devils. Once again the team was
nursing its injuries, but this time
the skeletal crew could not overcome adversity.
The hard-hitting game was
closely contested as the two teams

find themselves knotted at 3-3. At

The Punchline
By Christopher T. McColl
The punchline is this: to sleep,
perchance to dream for just a few
more minutes, honest, I swear,
just let me lie here . . . .
Here's the thing. Anyone with
a foolproof guar-ron-teed absolutely surefire no-doubt-aboutit way to get up in the morning
the minute you need to, raise your
hand.
I thought so.
It can't be done. Impossible.
An integral step in the evolutionary cycle that brought us up
from the basic primeval sludge of
the earth into the highly advanced sludge of humanity that we are
today involved a snipping of those
segments of DNA that control our
metabolic rhythms and our ability to make it on time to 8:00
classes. All that talk you hear
about "biological clocks" on
cable health networks and in triathlete magazines is a load of
monkey liver that was invented to
makes us feel better about our own
shortcomings and to explain the
existence of certain freaks who
not only get up on time, but also
have complete mental control
over that "sleep-mousse" that
manages to turn one's hair into
one of the bush-sculptures at Walt
Disney World.
What's this? Protest from those
neatly-groomed peppy freaks?
Everyone has a biological clock?
Nobody really has a problem getting up'?
Your honor, Exhibit A. The
Snooze Alarm.
I've lived with one of my two
present roommates now for three
years. During two of those years
(almost), we were on crew
together. Part of crew training requires that those participants get
up for morning workout the night
before.
In any event. This particular
roommate of mine is what we call
a "heavy sleeper," which really
means that he requires a
defibrillator to regain consciousness every morning. Accordingly, he has an alarm clock
that is Armageddon itself. It's
your standard radio-alarm issue,

circa 1975 or so, with flipswitches instead of touchsensitive buttons. Ah, but then,
it's not standard, it's magic, for
this unassuming clock can instantly transform any Debby Boone

Bush: Less than humane
While President George Bush and Hopkins dignitaries participated in Commemoration Day exercises in Shriver Hall,
several Hopkins-affiliated groups gathered in protest, in the
rain, on the steps of Levering Hall. Students and other members
of the Homewood community, including such diverse groups
as the Women's Center, Students for Environmental Action,
the Progressive Student Union and the School of Public Health,
rallied against the University's decision to select President Bush
as the speaker for the Commemoration Day theme: "Doctoring in America."
During the ceremony Bush received an honorary Doctor of
Humane Letters degree. Unfortunately, the Bush Adminstration's actions toward public health have been less than humane.
In this fiscal year alone, the Administration proposes to cut
federal public health expenditures by 7 percent. The Administration has already limited Medicaid funding for abortions,
and deeply cut funding for family planning centers and contraceptive research.

With the importance that Bush claims to place on the notion
of family and American values, how is it that 500,000 women
each year give birth to children without medical care and that
42 percent of families headed by single women live beneath
the poverty line? A consequence of this poverty is that 40,000
infants die in their first year; one-half of these deaths can be
prevented with increased access to prenatal and maternal health
care
These facts and figures should be kept in mind when Bush
speaks of his Administration's commitment to health care. He
refers to Secretary Sullivan's evaluation of cost, quality,and
effectiveness of care, and of a program to study overall treatment. Such kind and gentle rhetoric is nice enough when looking down from the House on the hill, but an active public health
policy is long overdue. Surely a more appropriate Commemoration speaker than President Bush could have been found to
discuss "Doctoring in America."

A new mission for Johns Hopkins
While President Muller has done a great deal for the Johns
Hopkins University as a whole over the past twenty years, the
undergraduate division has not received as much attention as
it deserves. While the School of Arts and Sciences still offers
a combination of small classes and a truly worldly faculty that
few schools can match, current budgetary problems have shaken
student confidence in the University's commitment to its
undergraduates.
Our next president must respond to this unease not with
dollars alone, but with a revolutionary approach to
undergraduate education: It is time to reinstitute the core curriculum and, in the liberal arts, the mandatory senior thesis.
These must be part of a three-pronged philosophy which will
decisively set a Hopkins undergraduate education apart from
all other universities.
First, our liberal arts must be kept from falling into the abyss
of grade inflation which scars so many other schools; an 'A'
should be a rare occurrence. One step towards arresting the slide
towards grade inflation (still far more controlled here than at
Yale or Stanford—average grades at those schools are said to
be nearly 3.8) is to reintroduce the mandatory senior thesis,
a victim of the turbulent 1960's. It is ludicrous that English,
Writing Seminars, and Political Science majors, for example,
are not required to submit a supervised thesis in order to
graduate. A thesis is an invaluable learning experience, and
would allow professors and future employers/graduate schools
to see if students had gotten anything out of four expensive
years. It would also put Hopkins on the academic map as a
school which was extremely serious about substantive

undergraduate liberal arts education.
Second, all students, whether in the sciences or in the
humanities, should begin with a common core curriculum.
Twenty-five years ago, all Hopkins students had to take two
terms of Occidental Civilization. This should be reinstated, in
conjunction with courses which reflect the globalization of late
twentieth-century life. Liberal arts students must also be required to take some hard sciences. The idea that such students
don't need a strong quantitative background is absurd and hardly befits an institution with Hopkins' ancestry.
Third, the University must keep class sizes down. The difficulty some professors are already having with hordes of
students begging for their seminars is alarming. Either the
University must expand its course offerings, or accept fewer
students. There are plenty of professors who do not teach much,
if at all. And there are plenty of other schools where sharp
undergraduates can go if they receive inadequate instruction
here. Worst of all, large classes are a betrayal of Hopkins'
greatest claim to fame: academic intimacy.
A well-conceived philosophy of what an undergraduate
education at Hopkins should be would help to restore confidence
in the Arts and Sciences, and would lend greater meaning to
what is often an unpleasant grind. The promotion of a core curriculum and the return of such challenges as the senior thesis,
would restore the lustre which is often missing from liberal
arts degrees, and broaden the minds of sometimes myopic scientists. Most of all, a clear philosophy, based on this University's unique and proud past, would give the Arts and Sciences
a sense of direction and meaning.

In tht Age of Show Business
everything is entertaining. With
the ascension of television as our
main brm of public discourse,
Americans have come to expect
that even the most serious topics
be broaght to them in an exciting
visual manner. Nowhere is this
more evident than a typical
broadcast of network news. The
musical theme, attractive
graphcs, and handsome anchornen offer a smooth transition
from television's normal programining. While the viewer is
expected to distinguish between
sitcoms and public information,
the harmat of network news
makes this a difficult process. As
Robert MacNeil of the MacNeilLehrer News Hour has suggested, the assumptions controlling a news program are "that
bite-sized is best, that complexity must be avoided, that nuances
are dispensable, that qualifications impede the simple message,
that visual stimulation is a
substitu:e for thought, and that
is an
verbal precision
anachronism." This condemnation o television news may
distress the daily viewer, but it
should not come as a surprise.
Entertainment is the business of
television and news programs are
no exception.
Television news is never
presented in context. It would
take most of the evening to explain the intricacies in the British
Government every time a decision by Prime Minister Thatcher
was anncunced. Without this
information,
backgrotmd
however, the decision becomes
just another fact in a series of
fragmen:s presented by the
newscas:er. Incredibly, most
Americans cannot recall a single
item of news just a few minutes
after watching a news program.
This is he direct result of television's eniphasis on entertainment.
The viewer's ability to mentally
address each topic is curtailed by
a rapid succession of visual images accompanied by unsubstantive commentary. There is no
time for rational thought. The
viewer is set adrift in a sea of
trivia and told to fend for himself.
Television news must accomplish the dual goals of relaying information in an entertaining and rapid manner. The
average length of each shot on a
network sitcom is 3.5 seconds.
On a typical edition of the evening news, it is approximately two
seconds. One can hardly keep up

with the overwhelming visual
display and still distinguish what
is important. A story on Mikhail
Gorbachev's speech in West Germany might be accompanied by
images of people cheering in the
streets, opinion polls, and the
White House, all of which have
only a tenuous relationship to the
content of the presentation. The
story is then followed by a
McDonald's commercial, which
is accompanied by images of people cheering in the streets, opinion polls, and the White House,
all of which have only a tenuous
relationship to the product being
marketed. The juxtaposition
seems clear.
The real problem with television news is that it is on television. It might help to draw a comparison. Though the smoke signal
was once a popular form of communication, it is safe to assume
that Indians did not discuss the
meaning of life through this
medium. Muchawapeh would
have run out of wood before he
was able to convey his first
philosophic axiom to the
neighboring tribe. The form
denied the content. Television
news is faced with a similar
dilemma. With its emphasis on
visual imagery, television works
against the presentation of ideas.
Images supersede the content of
any verbal message. It would be
difficult to concentrate on the
news if the anchormen came on
without his clothes. His appearance would mitigate his ability to present information. Less
outlandish images produce the
same effect. The form of television serves as a barrier to effective communication except on a
basic, emotional level.
Neil Postman has suggested
that "The problem with television
is not that it presents us with
entertaining subject matter, but
that it presents all subject matter
as entertaining." Nowhere is this
more evident than in the format
of television news. Producers are
confined by a medium that does
not allow for the same rational
presentation of ideas as does the
written word. One would not
pause in a book for a commercial
break. When television attempts
to present serious discourse it is
simply doing its viewers a disservice. In its own way television is
as limited as the smoke signal.
Only when we realize this can we
understand that the line between
knowledge and ignorance is easily blurred.

restrictions upon outside contributions, why is it less desirable

editorial commentary submitted
from the inside? I can only hope
that the News-Letter recognizes
the folly of this new policy in the
very near future.

of

Steinberg on schisms:
Rabbi discusses divisions
throughout Jewish history

by Neeli Ben-David

by Shani Miller
The Union of Jewish Graduate
Students lecture series is back for
the spring semester. Last week's
speaker was Rabbi Benjamin
Steinberg, principal of the Bais
Yaakov School. The evening's
topic was "Schisms in Judaism."
Rabbi Steinberg began the lecture with the joke of the Jew who
was shipwrecked on a dessert
island: the man built two
synagogues, one to pray in and
one in which he would not be
caught dead.
Steinberg then discussed
various schisms in Jewish history,
beginning with the Biblical accounts of Korah rebelling against
Moses and the later formation of
the breakaway Kingdom on Israel
from the Kingdom of Judah.
Steinberg established two
general types of splits: ones that
operate "within the parameters of
Judaism" and ones that operate
from without.
He cited the case of HiIlel and
Shammai, two eminent rabbis
who lived roughly 2000 years
ago and who disagreed on nearly every major issue that came
before them. This difference in
rabbinical opinion did not cause
the divisiveness that characterized other schisms such as the birth
of the Sadducees.
The Sadducees rejected rabbinical
authority completely and based
their interpretation of the Bible on
a literal understanding of the text.
What developed was a sect whose
rituals only slightly resembled
those of traditional Judaism.
Hillel and Shammai disagreed
within the traditional legal
framework of Judaism; both of
their opinions remained within
the philosophical bounds of
Judaism. But the Sadducees rejected rabbinical authority come

0

pletely, and as rabbinical
leadership is essential to the integrity of the religion, this crisis
resulted in a major schism.
Similarly, early Christianity
was loosely based on Jewish
traditions. However, since it rejected the Temple services and
revoked the Sabbath as the traditional day of rest, it was largely
unpopular with the Jewish community. The Temple was a major symbol to the Jews, and the
Sabbath even today remains an
integral part of Jewish life.
Here again was a case of a
group moving beyond the bounds
of traditional Judaism. The difference between the Sadducees
and Christianity is that Christianity drew non-Jewish converts and
evolved into its own religion,
while the Sadducees remained a
strictly Jewish sect.
Steinberg moved on to the
Karaite schism in 700 A.D. in
Babylonia. Mirroring the Sadducees, the Karaites reject the
rabbinical authority. In the 1100's
Maimonides noted in his essays
that the Karaites remained Jews.
There is even a small community of Karaites still in existence in
the Old City of Jerusalem.
Steinberg followed with a quick
review of European history
leading to the formation of
Reform and Conservative
Judaism. He noted that the
Reform movement was an
outgrowth of the German
Enlightenment, the Age of
Reason. There was a general deemphasis of religion on the continent at the time, and by the turn
of the nineteenth century there
was a tremendous push to
simplify Jewish tradition and
ritual.
Conservatism was born out of
a concern that the Reform had

A Shrewd Pastiche of Styles
Jimmy Smith—Prime Time
(Milestone)
Jimmy Smith has been a
premier jazz organist for nearly
35 years, and his first record
since 1985 is an impressive,
democratic collection of songs
and styles that reach as far back
as the swing era. "Straightahead" is how his record company describes it, but don't
believe it. Although "Prime
Time" is composed both of standards and some competent
originals, Smith and his band tug
this music in directions that are
both beguiling and unexpected.
The tugging isn't random,
however: Smith dips shrewdly into the wells of big band, bebop,
rhythm and blues, and even free
jazz to enhance his arrangements.
What makes it all so democratic
is the unfailing subtlety that, time
and again, wrings a convincing
result from the most unlikely
sources. Some of the players in
Smith's band (e.g. the tenor saxophonists) don't always meet the
challenge; the rhythm section
seems at times to play it safe for
their benefit. But the organist
himself is sensational, punching
out rich clusters of bass notes and

tiptoeing through sparse treble
runs that drift elegantly over the
rhythm section.
Tellingly, the most familiar
compositions on "Prime Time"
are also those that most succeed.
Kenny Burrell's "Here Comes
C.T.," written for trumpeter
Clark Terry, is at once strident
and funky. The perennial
"Honky Tonk" boasts an arrangement that puts the highs
where the lows should be, and
vice versa, but somehow it
works—and Smith revivifies one
of the most tired tunes in jazz.
The album's highlight, however,
is a dense rendition of Duke Ellington's "C Jam Blues." Here
the funk is all but absent, and
Smith's sextet expounds with the
energy and economy of a fullfledged big band.

Mid-winter movie surprises are

Brickman's "Men Don't Leave"

Maryland. John's an architect,

Everything's in order, but it

that things aren't going to stay
that way.
When John is killed in an explosion, "Men Don't Leave"

shifts into surreal overdrive. Beth
wanders aimlessly through
hospital corridors (Johns Hopkins
Hospital, to be precise) to identify his body. She ends up in a kitchen basement, slumping into a
corner as endless rows of Asian
employees slice up raw chicken
for hospital meals.
This is just one of Brickman's
peculiar but compelling visual
selections. "Men Don't Leave"
opens with stunning expressive
images of Matt racing a train as
he runs towards his home on a
rainy night; it's as if Brickman
were holding a carrot in front of
his camera. And then Matt is inside, his gentle voice reminiscing

Like the rest of "Men Don't

Director John Boorman probably thought he was being
stylish when he put the credits for

Actually, he couldn't have

this frivolous, seemingly unending film is a dull exhibit not
worth any price of admission.
"Where the Heart Is" certainly
isn't from the realist school.
Dabney Coleman plays Stewart
McBain, a "successful demolition contractor" (whatever that
means) who blows up buildings
in a single bound. Stewart has a
spoiled,
His
problem:
unbelievably artsy kids have the
"won't leave home" syndrome.
They play loud music and carry
on, amoral and valueless, so he
finally kicks them out. Dad forces
them to live in an abandoned
tenement on his Brooklyn property, foraging for food and shiver-

ing in the cold.
One quick question: Who
spoiled these kids? Who made
them into such irrepressible, intolerable wretches? Could it be
their mother and father, who
spout such witticisms as "The
world is at your feet, don't step
on it"? Perhaps.
Although there are three
children, they are basically one
toad with three heads. Daphne
(Uma Thurman) is quasimystical, a magician's assistant;
Jimmy (David Hewlett) is quasitechnical, writing computer
games(although he mainly seems
to play them); and Chloe (Suzy
Amis) is quasi-artistic, experimenting with trompe l'oeil—
look it up.
When these talentless minions
run out of money, they hire
boarders. What a delightful
romp! Among the guests are the
stock broker who unwittingly
leads to Stewart's demise, the
young male fashion designer who

like "Esacpe from Witch Mountain."

with which to sympathize in
"Where the Heart Is." Uma
Thurman is the only bright note;
she slinks in and out of the film
with undeniable grace. Still, even
she is a mockery, a mere parody
of real wealthy people. Boorman
can't score points with his moral
when he tries so hard to—and
succeeds at—painting the McBain
family as unreal.
Even when McBain loses his
company and all of his material

The Office of Admissions is opening a search for admissions interns for the 1990-1991 school year. We are
looking for people-oriented students to assist in the
recruitment process by conducting the traditional oncampus interview. Ideal candidates will enjoy speaking
with prospective students and their parents. Students
must be poised and mature, and posess tact, diplomacy
and the ability to put high school students and their
parents at ease.

next fall in good standing. Interns must be able to talk
about Johns Hopkins in an informed and positive way,
have a desire to participate in the recruitment process,
and be comfortable interacting with others.

interviews with prospective students, and meeting their
parents and responding to their questions and concerns.

reports of each interview. This will involve three or four
hour-long interviews each week from mid-September
through April. Further responsibilities pertinent to the

Admissions as the year progresses.

March 12, 13 & 14, with second interviews scheduled
on March 26, 27 and 28. The training program for those
interns selected will be just after final examinations and
at the beginning of first semester next year. Interns
must be available at these times.
Any student interested should send a letter indicating
his or her interest and listing two references, to Richard
M. Fuller, Director of Admissions. Both references must
be members of the Johns Hopkins community,
preferably one member from the faculty and one from
the administration. Students should apply by March 9.

Why is there fluoride in toothpaste?
It's a good idea to brush after sweets, since sugar is food for bacteria
that live in your mouth. These bacteria produce acids which eat away
at the enamel, the mineral outer coat of teeth. The inner layer, the
dentine, is weaker and more sensitive to the acids and will start to
rot away without a protective enamel surface.
The minerals get stuck in the plaque, but teeth do reclaim them,
and fluoride appears to speed the process.
Also, enamel on children's teeth is developing. The little fluoride
ion probably steps in for bigger minerals, producing a tighter, and
thus stronger, crystal structure of enamel.

Men capture 20th consecutive post-season title
by Michele Royce
On Wednesday, February 14,
the Hopkins contingent arrived in
St. Louis for the 1990 UAA
Swimming and Diving Championships and were greeted by
rain and comments about the
team's lack of ability this season.
However, when they returned on
Sunday, they were accompanied
by sunshine and a new respect
from the other teams in the conference. Both the men's and
women's teams from Hopkins
were awarded the title of 1990
UAA Swimming and Diving
Champions.
The conference championships
are held as a 3-day meet among
the 8 schools in the UAA which
compete in swimming, often for
the only time during the season.
This year, the meet was held at
Washington University, St.
Louis. Each day consisted of a
morning session of preliminary
heats, in which the swimmers
competed against each other and
the clock in order to place in one
of the top 16 spots while the evening featured the finals, composed of a championship heat (for
places 1 through 8 from the
prelims) and a consolation heat
(for places 9 to 16), which determine the points to be awarded to
the teams and individuals.
Despite the comments that
were overheard about the
Hopkins men being noncontenders for this meet, and the
\wren having a smali-rossibility of fighting for second place,
the Jays went into the meet with
an extremely positive attitude.
Both teams were defending champions in the UAA, and all of the

swimmers felt extremely wellrested. In fact, the statements only served to spur the team on as
they decided that they would prove everyone wrong. And they did
so decisively.
The initial day of events set the
tone for the entire meet. Both
teams would take the lead with
the first event and never relinquish it. As Assistant Coach Jim
"Popeye" Cutrone said, "We
dominated the meet from the first
day on. It was an excellent
meet."
The other teams began to question their assuredness when, in
the second event of the day, the
first heat of the Men's 200 yard
freestyle relay, freshman Eric
Steidinger led off with a time of
20.93 seconds—a time that would
have crushed the pool and UAA
records had it been set in an individual event. It did, however,
represent the first male swimming member of the Hopkins team
to qualify for the NCAA Division
III Championships. He was
followed by classmate Aaron
Osborne with a split of 20.7
seconds off of a relay start. The
relay was filled out by freshmen
Mike Zelman and Ryan Gill, who
finished with a time of
1:25.86—a new pool, UAA,and
Hopkins record that would last
until that evening when Steidinger
was joined by junior Steve
Muchow and seniors Mike Costa
and John Hsu to win the event
with a time of 1:24.26. When
asked about the fact that the B
relay (usually the slower relay)
was led by such quick sprinters,
Cutrone merely responded that it
was a Freshman Relay, an indication of continuing excellence in

the future.
The domination of the Jays did
not end with that event. On the
first night, 94 percent of the
Hopkins swimmers who swam in
the morning made it to the evening heats (33 of 35), and in that
first night Hopkins had six firstplace winners (two individual)
and three second-place swimmers. Junior Melanie Chellman
took first in the 200-yard individual medley and in the process set a new pool record, and
qualified for the 1990 Hopkins
national team. After being
sidelined with an elbow injury for
the first half of the season,junior
John Paul Munnich qualified for
Nationals with a second place
time of 4:42.27 in the 500-yard
freestyle. "I really didn't believe
I would qualify this year," said
Munnich once the truth had sunk
in.
The first day was not one of
complete happiness. Senior co-

captain Mary Price missed the
qualifying standard in the 50 yard
freestyle by 1/100th of a second;
she touched the wall with a
season best time of 25.16
seconds.
On the second day, the coaches
hoped for an even better performance as they felt that Hopkins
was stronger in the featured
events than those of the previous
day. Surprisingly, the only individual qualifiers for the
Hopkins national team were not
event winners. Freshman
Danielle Bird took third place in
the 200-yard freestyle with a time
of 1:58.67, and classmate Jim
Quinn finished the 100-yard
freestyle with a time of 1:00.08
and second place. Both the men's
and women's 800 freestyle relay
teams also qualified for Nationals
as each captured first place, as
well as the pool record. Hopkins
also took first and second place
in both the men's and women's

100-yard backstroke. Price and
junior co-captain Amy Parke
(1:03.41 and 1:04.03) took the
honors in the women's event,
while seniors Mark Rhoades and
Chris Hussin did so for the men
with times of 55.00 and 55.08
respectively. Junior Scott Herrick
also showed tremendous ability
when he took first place in 400
yard individual medley and set a
new pool record with a time of
4:16.66.
The final night of competition
was accompanied by an air of excitement, as the teams began with
cheers for themselves and for
each other. The University of
Chicago performed an army/synchronized swimming/diving exhibition cheer that included the
new found respect that the other
teams had found for Hopkins.
After the seniors were recognized, the competition began for a
final time and the cheering increased. In the first event of the

by Andy Chien
After beating
Western
Maryland convincingly to earn
their first-ever trip to the Middle
Atlantic Conference playoffs, the
Jays lost a 63-61 heartbreaker on
the road in the opening round to
Moravian, the MAC Southeast
champions. The loss eliminated
the Jays from the playoffs.
Hopkins finished with an 18-7
record, the best ever for a

Hopkins women's basketball
team. Two of the losses were in
overtime to national top-ten
Franklin & Marshall, and another
loss was by three points to
Washington University, then
ranked sixth in the nation.
In the Moravian loss, Sylke
Knuppel led the Jays in scoring
with 14 points while shooting
67% from the field and grabbing
seven rebounds. Sophomore
center Julie Slye and sophomore

forward Kerni McTiernan each
pulled down a game-high I 1
boards, as Hopkins outrebounded the Greyhounds 52-44.
Point guard Tracy Williams
handed out six assists in addition
to scoring 10 points and making
four steals. Junior tri-captain
Kristie Kantowski, the only other
Jay in double-figures, added 10 ,
points and five rebounds.
The Jays' leading scorer of the
season, tri-captain Juliane
Rolapp, was held to only nine
points before fouling out. Rolapp
also had five assists and four
rebounds.
With two minutes left in the
game, Hopkins was ahead 59-55,
but Moravian scored five quick
unanswered points to take a 60-59
lead. Rolapp was called for an intentional foul, disqualifying her
with less than one minute to play.
The Greyhounds' Julie Endler,
who led all scorers with 27
points, sank both free-throws to
put her team up 62-59 with 23
seconds left in the game. Another
foul gave Moravian a one-andone opportunity, but the shooter
only made the first, putting Moravian up 63-59. Sylke Knuppel
missed a three-pointer, but the
Jays sank the rebound as time ran
out.
Hopkins led Moravian in
almost every statistical category,
but Moravian made 7-of-18 from
three-point range while the Jays
shot only 1-for-2 from behind the
stripe. Hopkins held Moravian to
a mere 37% field-goal shooting,
while the Jays shot 39% from the
field for the game.

The Johns Hopkins ice hockey
team started its spring semester
season by going 1-1-1 last week.
As a result of the busy week of
action, the team pushed its record
to 10-5-1 overall and 6-3-1 in the
Mason Dixon League.
The Jays started the week with
a home game against Bucknell.
Hopkins jumped out to a two-goal
lead early in the first period on
goals by seniors Jack Calkins and
Pierre DeMatos but proved
unable to hold the lead. The effects of the long Christmas layoff
were evident as the Jays combined sloppy defensive play and an
uninspired offense on the way to
losing a 5-2 decision.
In the next contest, the Blue
Jays rebounded with a narrow 6-5
win at UMBC. Despite missing
the entire second line for the
game, Hopkins used tenacious

forechecking and a hawking
defense to overcome the absence
of key players. Jack Calkins lead
the offense by recording a
hat trick, while Craig Hampton
and Mike Holmes anchored the
defense.
The game saw four lead
changes, but a tired Blue Jay
squad was able to hold on to a late
6-5 lead due largely to superb
goaltending by Pierre Chevrier.
"I was really proud of the way
our guys hung in there. The other
team had superior personnel this
day, but we wanted it more,"
commented coach Steve Wirth.
Looking to follow one win with
another, the Jays traveled to
Dickinson to take on the Red
Devils. Once again the team was
nursing its injuries, but this time
the skeletal crew could not overcome adversity.
The hard-hitting game was
closely contested as the two teams
